questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with longstanding hip osteoarthritis presents with complaints of constipation and loose stool. She undergoes a sigmoidoscopy. A rectal biopsy shows pigment-laden macrophages in the lamina propria. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The pigment-laden macrophages suggest that there is melanosis coli. The most common association is with laxatives.
  • To a lesser extent, melanosis coli is also associated with ulcerative colitis.

Melanosis coli:

  • Melanosis coli is a benign, reversible condition characterised by lipofuscin pigment in macrophages within the colonic lamina propria, typically arising from prolonged laxative use.
  • It often affects older adults using these stimulants for constipation relief and is identifiable by pigment-laden macrophages on biopsy.
  • Chronic use of anthraquinone-containing stimulant laxatives is by far the most common cause. Examples include senna, cascara, aloe vera, rhubarb, frangula, and other herbal remedies.
  • These compounds pass undigested to the colon, are converted by bacteria to active forms, induce apoptosis of the epithelial cells, and ultimately result in pigment deposition in macrophages.
  • The condition typically emerges within 4-12 months of regular laxative use, and is extremely common in long-term users (e.g. 75-95% prevalence).
  • Less commonly, similar pigmentation has been observed with chronic diarrhoea, inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), NSAID use, or vitamin E deficiency-though these are rare causes. (Other options ruled out)

questions.text:
A 51-year-old presents with tiredness and heavy periods. She is known to drink large amounts of alcohol. Her investigations reveal:
Haemoglobin 7.3 g/dl
MCV 72 fL
white cell count 7500/μ
platelet count 250000/μ
serum ferritin 7 μg/L, (15-300)
She was commenced on oral iron therapy one month later, but her haemoglobin concentration was 7.8 g/dl. What is the likely cause of the failure of her haemoglobin to respond?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • An increase in haemoglobin of approximately 1 g/dL after one month of oral iron therapy is considered an adequate response in iron deficiency anaemia.
  • In this patient, her haemoglobin rose only from 7.3 to 7.8 g/dL, which is far less than expected.

According to guidelines, inadequate haemoglobin response should prompt consideration of:

  • Ongoing blood loss
  • Poor absorption or malabsorption
  • Incorrect diagnosis
  • Noncompliance (poor adherence) to therapy

Given her low ferritin, confirming iron deficiency and the minimal haemoglobin rise at one month, the most likely cause is poor compliance with therapy

Explanation of other options:

Folate deficiency(Option A) will cause a Megaloblastic picture with MCV>100 fL

Sideroblastic anaemia(Option C) would cause an increase in serum iron and ferritin.

Alcoholism(Option D) affects hematopoiesis via marrow suppression, macrocytosis, folate deficiency, and sometimes sideroblastic or megaloblastic changes, but it does not usually cause poor response to oral iron if iron deficiency is correct and the patient is compliant

questions.text: A 46-year-old man has a diagnosis of celiac disease. He presents with a one-month history of intermittent, colicky, central abdominal pain and weight loss of 5 kg. There is positive faecal occult blood. What is the most appropriate investigation?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Colonoscopy is necessary to exclude a colonic carcinoma.
  • There is a relatively high prevalence of colorectal neoplasia among older patients with coeliac disease who can present with iron deficiency or altered bowel habits.
  • Celiac disease is a systemic, immune-driven condition that damages the small intestine upon gluten exposure.
  • Diagnosis relies on serology and confirmatory biopsy, followed by a lifelong gluten-free diet.
  • Early recognition and management minimise long-term complications and support intestinal healing.
  • Barium enema is inferior in sensitivity and doesn't allow biopsy-so it's not preferred. (Option B ruled out.)
  • Duodenal biopsy is redundant here; the patient already has a confirmed celiac diagnosis, and new symptoms suggest lower GI involvement rather than a relapse or celiac complication. (Option A ruled out.)
  • CT abdomen may pick up masses or complications, but it cannot definitively diagnose mucosal lesions and lacks the ability for biopsy or therapeutic intervention. (Option C ruled out.)

Key takeaways:

  • Up to half of patients presenting with Streptococcus bovis endocarditis have colorectal tumours.

questions.text: A 68-year-old man is admitted with a history of sudden onset abdominal pain, followed by watery diarrhoea and subsequent profuse rectal bleeding. He has been a smoker for 40 years and had a myocardial infarction 5 years ago. He has a family history of colon carcinoma. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The history of pain, diarrhoea and bleeding per rectum in a patient with vascular risk factors suggests large bowel infarction.
  • This clinical presentation is classic for ischemic colitis, where patients often experience acute cramping colic, urgent diarrhoea, and hematochezia within 24 hours.
  • Ischaemic bowel disease may be acute or chronic. Most cases result from arterial occlusion, usually of the superior mesenteric artery. The small bowel is not commonly involved.

Explanation of other options:

Sigmoid volvulus(Option A): Chronic constipation, abdominal distension, colicky pain, sometimes vomiting. Early onset diarrhoea and bright red blood can occur, but distension and constipation dominate.

Rectal carcinoma(Option C): Painless rectal bleeding, changes in bowel habits, tenesmus, sometimes weight loss or anaemia-but rarely acute onset, sudden pain, or diarrhoea.

Ulcerative colitis(Option D): Gradually developing bloody diarrhoea, cramping pain, urgency; may include systemic signs like fever-occurring over weeks or months.

choices.text: CT scan of the abdomen and upper GI endoscopy

questions.text:
A 76-year-old male is seen in the outpatient department. He reports weight loss over three months, but his history is otherwise unremarkable. On examination, his abdomen is soft with no palpable masses. A PR examination is normal. His blood tests show:
Hemoglobin 8.0 g/dL(12-16)
MCV 70 fL(80-96)
Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In a 76-year-old man presenting with iron deficiency anaemia (Hb 8.0 g/dL, MCV 70 fL) and weight loss without overt bleeding, the most appropriate evaluation is bidirectional endoscopy, i.e., both upper GI endoscopy and colonoscopy performed.
  • Iron deficiency anaemia in men or postmenopausal women strongly warrants investigation for GI malignancies or bleeding sources across the GI tract.
  • AGA guidelines recommend "bidirectional endoscopy" (both EGD + colonoscopy) in asymptomatic men with IDA.
  • Bidirectional endoscopy in elderly anaemic patients has a high diagnostic yield: about 49% upper GI lesions, ~32% lower GI lesions; 9.5% had both simultaneously.

Explanation of other options:

Abdominal x-ray and colonoscopy(Option A): X-rays are not diagnostic for mucosal lesions or tumours-they add no value.

CT scan of the abdomen and upper GI endoscopy(Option B): CT lacks sensitivity for early mucosal lesions like polyps; lower GI evaluation is still needed.

Sigmoidoscopy upper GI endoscopy(Option C): Sigmoidoscopy only examines the distal colon (≈50%), missing proximal colon lesions-colonoscopy is standard.

questions.text: A 72-year-old lady presented with dyspnoea and fever. She has a history of weight loss, which has been investigated with colonoscopy, which found a tumour of the sigmoid colon, and she is awaiting surgery. On examination, she has a systolic murmur, and an ECHO shows vegetations on the mitral valve. A diagnosis of infective endocarditis is made. Which of the following organisms is associated with a high incidence of colorectal tumours?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Up to half of patients presenting with Streptococcus bovis endocarditis have colorectal tumours

questions.text: A 68-year-old man has a 2 cm adenoma removed from his sigmoid colon. The biopsy results confirm an adenocarcinoma in situ with moderately differentiated dysplastic cells. The pathology report confirms total excision with clear resection margins. What is the most appropriate follow-up management for this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The first thing to note is that the question is about planned management. This patient has been picked up early and has had a tumour resected.
  • The US Multi-Society Task Force and AGA (2020) advise colonoscopy for patients with adenomas ≥10 mm or high-grade dysplasia. (Option C ruled out.)
  • His CEA would be normal and would not be expected to be elevated until the disease was quite established on the TNM scale.
  • Therefore, he should continue to be reviewed with colonoscopy annually for at least two years.
  • As there's no invasive cancer or lymph node involvement, systemic therapy or tumour marker surveillance is not required(Option A and B ruled out)

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with a history of abdominal discomfort that is relieved by passing stool. In the past month, his stools have been looser, and he has had a feeling of urgency and incomplete evacuation. His symptoms seem to be worse with eating. He has also noticed that he has passed mucus per rectum. He is overweight with a BMI of 28 kg/m2. His weight has fallen. He says that he has adjusted his diet in the last six months. Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Weight loss, tenesmus and a recent change in bowel habit all point towards an underlying diagnosis of colorectal cancer.
  • Onset of symptoms in later life and a relatively short duration (that is, weeks rather than years) also point towards a 'biological' cause rather than irritable bowel syndrome.
  • The passage of mucus per rectum is a normal physiological function and not indicative of underlying pathology.
  • The symptoms are not suggestive of malabsorption.

Explanation of other options:

Diverticulitis(Option B): Presents with left lower quadrant pain, fever, and signs of inflammation-not seen here.

Inflammatory bowel disease (Option C): Typically shows bloody diarrhoea, abdominal pain, and systemic symptoms. Mucus alone without bleeding leans away from IBD.

Irritable bowel syndrome (Option D): Although IBS can cause urgency, incomplete evacuation, and mucus, alarm symptoms (bleeding, weight loss, age >50, symptom change) require ruling out organic disease before this diagnosis

choices.text: Germline mutation of the STK11 gene on chromosome 19
Heterozygous mutation of the MYH gene
Loss of the APC gene on chromosome 5

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man was found to have iron deficiency anaemia when he went to donate blood. Generally, the patient was very well. He had a good appetite, his weight was steady, and he ate a normal diet. He had a normal bowel habit and had never passed any blood, mucus or diarrhoea in his stools. There is no history of any overt blood loss. His general practitioner got an open-access endoscopy, which was normal; duodenal biopsies were unremarkable. His father had died of what he thought was secondary liver and lung cancer, but he was unsure. On general physical examination, he was fit and athletic. The skin and mucosal membranes were unremarkable. Vitals were normal. Heart sounds were normal, and the chest was clear. His abdomen was soft and nontender with no palpable masses or organs. Rectal examination was normal. On viewing the rectal mucosa through a rigid sigmoidoscope, the colonic mucosa was covered in innumerable polyps.
What specific genetic abnormality is responsible for this appearance?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • A 24-year-old man with iron deficiency anaemia, normal endoscopy, and numerous colonic polyps on rigid sigmoidoscopy likely has Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP).
  • This condition is typically caused by a germline mutation in the APC gene on chromosome 5, leading to the development of numerous adenomatous polyps in the colon and rectum.
  • If left untreated, there's a nearly 100% risk of colorectal cancer by the age of 40. The condition is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern.
  • The patient will need a full colonoscopy and biopsy, but the information presented is highly suggestive of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), caused by the loss of the APC gene on the short arm of chromosome 5.

Explanation of other options:

Germline mutation of the STK11 gene on chromosome 19(Option A):

  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder caused by a germline mutation of the STK11 (serine threonine kinase 11) gene, usually located on the long arm of chromosome 19.
  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is associated with intestinal hamartomatous polyps, but is usually (90%) associated with perioral pigmentation.

Mutations in mismatch repair genes(Option D):

  • Hereditary nonpolyposis colon cancer (HNPCC) and MYC polyposis do not cause multiple polyps as suggested in this case.
  • In HNPCC, affected individuals inherit a mutation in one of several genes involved in DNA mismatch repair, including MSH2, MLH1, and PMS2.

Heterozygous mutation of the MYH gene(Option B):

  • Heterozygous mutations in the MYH gene have been associated with a phenotype of multiple colorectal adenomas with or without cancer.

questions.text: You review an 84-year-old lady in the gastroenterology clinic. She has been referred by her family doctor with a three-month history of change in bowel habit and weight loss. Recently, she has noticed PR bleeding with blood in the stool. There is a history of ischaemic heart disease with a previous myocardial infarction three years ago. She suffers from stable angina and congestive cardiac failure. Which of the following investigations would be most appropriate to make the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Colorectal carcinomaneeds to be excluded in this case. Three-quarters of cases occur in people aged over 65y. Around 50% survive for over 5 years following diagnosis.

In people with major comorbidities:

  • Flexible sigmoidoscopy, then barium enema, should be offered for patients with major comorbidity. CT colonography is an alternative if the local radiology service is competent in this technique.
  • In this case, the presence of congestive cardiac failure is a major comorbidity. A flexible sigmoidoscopy should therefore be first line (especially as she complains of fresh red bleeding, increasing the chance that this is a left-sided lesion).
  • A small dose of oral contrast is administered 24 hours before the procedure, and then the colon is imaged using helical CT scanning.
  • Most CT colonography protocols require the use of bowel cleansing agents. The advantages over colonoscopy include no requirement for sedation, smaller risk of perforation, and extra-colonic pathology can also be demonstrated.

In people without major comorbidities:

  • About the investigation of colorectal carcinoma, colonoscopy should be offered to patients without major comorbidity. If a lesion suspicious of cancer is detected, a biopsy should be performed to obtain a histological diagnosis.
  • If the colonoscopy is incomplete, it should be repeated, or CT colonography or barium enema should be performed.
  • If a lesion suspicious of cancer is detected on CT colonography, a colonoscopy and biopsy should be offered (unless there are absolute contraindications).
  • CT chest, abdomen, and pelvis should be offered after the diagnosis is made to estimate the stage of the disease. Patients with a rectal tumour should also undergo MRI to assess local disease.
  • Endorectal ultrasound can then be offered if MRI shows disease amenable to local excision (or if MRI is contraindicated).
  • Digital rectal examination is not part of the staging investigations.

questions.text: Iron absorption is decreased by which of the following in a meal?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Dietary composition affects the biological availability and use of nutrients. For example, iron absorption may be impaired by large amounts of calcium or lead; likewise, non-heme iron uptake may be impaired by a lack of ascorbic acid and amino acids in the meal.
